00034 // For multithreading NCPU should be set in the Makefile.  NCPU must be greater
00035 // than or equal to the maximum number of threads that will be detected by OpenMP
00036 // If NCPU > omp_get_max_threads, some memory will be wasted, but it's harmless
00037 // otherwise.
00038 //
00039 // Define NCPU=1 if value not set in Makefile
00040 #ifndef NCPU
00041 #define NCPU 1
00042 #endif

00071     // MAX_NUM_DISEASES sets the size of stl::bitsets and static arrays used throughout FRED
00072     // to store disease-specific flags and pointers; set to the smallest possible value 
00073     // for optimal performance and memory usage
00074     static const int MAX_NUM_DISEASES = 1;
00075     // Change this constant and recompile to allow more threads.  For efficiency should be
00076     // equal to OMP_NUM_THREADS value that will be used.  If OMP_NUM_THREADS greater than
00077     // MAX_NUM_THREADS is used, FRED will abort the run.
00078     static const int MAX_NUM_THREADS = NCPU;

00235 namespace fred {

00237   /*
00238    * This is a space optimization for small bitsets (uses 1 byte rather than 8)
00239    * Most methods from std::bitset are implemented, however, notably, operator[] is not,
00240    * nor are operator&, operator*
00241    */
00242   template< int n_bits >
00243   struct tiny_bitset {
00244     typedef unsigned char BitType;
00245     BitType bits;
00246 
00247     tiny_bitset() {
00248       if ( n_bits > sizeof( BitType ) ) {
00249         fprintf( stderr, "This specialized bitset is limited to %zu bits.  If a larger bitset is needed, use std::bitset\n", sizeof( BitType ) );
00250 
00251       }
00252       assert( n_bits <= sizeof( BitType ) );
00253       reset();
00254     }
00255     void reset() { bits = 0; }
00256     void reset( int pos ) { bits  &= ~( (BitType) 1 << pos ); }
00257     void set() { bits = ~0; }
00258     void set( int pos ) { bits |= ( (BitType) 1 << pos ); }
00259     int size() {
00260       // Published in 1988, the C Programming Language 2nd Ed. (by Brian W. Kernighan and Dennis M. Ritchie) mentions this in exercise 2-9.
00261       // Don Knuth pointed out that this method "was first published by Peter Wegner in CACM 3 (1960), 322.
00262       // Also discovered independently by Derrick Lehmer and published in 1964 in a book edited by Beckenbach.)"
00263       BitType c; // c accumulates the total bits set in v
00264       for (c = 0; bits; c++) {
00265         bits &= bits - 1; // clear the least significant bit set
00266       }
00267       return c;
00268     }
00269     bool any() const { return bits > 0; }
00270     bool none() const { return bits == 0; }
00271     bool test( int pos ) const { return bits & ( (BitType) 1 << pos ); } 
00272   };
00273 
00274

00276   /* 
00277    * bitset big enough to store flags for MAX_NUM_DISEASES
00278    * Global::MAX_NUM_DISEASES should be equal to Global::Diseases
00279    * for efficiency. 
00280    * IMPORTANT NOTE TO THE PROGRAMMER: 'Diseases' may be less than
00281    * 'MAX_NUM_DISEASES' so care should be taken when performing operations
00282    * (such as any(), flip(), reset(), etc.) on a disease_bitset to avoid
00283    * unintended setting/resetting flags for non-existent diseases.
00284    *
00285    */
00286   typedef tiny_bitset<Global::MAX_NUM_DISEASES> disease_bitset;

00301   #ifdef _OPENMP
00302   
00303   #include <omp.h>
00304   struct Mutex {
00305     Mutex()   { omp_init_lock( & lock ); }
00306     ~Mutex()  { omp_destroy_lock( & lock ); }
00307     void Lock()   { omp_set_lock( & lock ); }
00308     void Unlock() { omp_unset_lock( & lock ); }
00309    
00310     Mutex( const Mutex & ) { omp_init_lock( & lock ); }
00311     Mutex & operator= ( const Mutex & ) { return *( this ); }
00312     omp_lock_t lock;
00313   };
00314 
00315   #else
00316   
00318   struct Mutex {
00319     void Lock() {}
00320     void Unlock() {}
00321   };
00322 
00323   static int omp_get_max_threads() {
00324     return 1; 
00325   }
00326 
00327   static int omp_get_num_threads() {
00328     return 1;
00329   }
00330 
00331   static int omp_get_thread_num() {
00332     return 0;
00333   }
00334   #endif

00337   struct Scoped_Lock {
00338     explicit Scoped_Lock( Mutex & m ) : mut( m ), locked( true ) { mut.Lock(); }
00339     ~Scoped_Lock() { Unlock(); }
00340     void Unlock()     { if ( !locked ) return; locked = false; mut.Unlock(); }
00341     void LockAgain()  { if (  locked ) return; mut.Lock(); locked = true; }
00342   private:
00343     Mutex & mut;
00344     bool locked;
00345     void operator=( const Scoped_Lock &);
00346     Scoped_Lock( const Scoped_Lock & );
00347   };
00348 
00349   // compare and swap currently only available using GCC atomic builtin
00350   // need to define behavior for other compilers 
00351   #ifdef __GNUC__
00352   template < typename T >
00353   inline static T compare_and_swap( T * p, T a, T b ) {
00354     return __sync_bool_compare_and_swap( p, a, b );
00355   }
00356   // Spin_Lock/Spin_Mutex:
00357   // This is a much lighter weight mutex.  The omp mutex defined above
00358   // requires 64 bytes of memory.  This spin mutex requires only 1.
00359   // The spin mutex will also perform better under some circumstances,
00360   // especially when wait time for acquisition of the lock is small.
00361   struct Spin_Mutex {
00362     bool locked;
00363     Spin_Mutex()  { locked = false; }
00364     void Lock()   { locked = true;  }
00365     void Unlock() { locked = false; }
00366   };
00367   // since we don't have compare and swap without the gcc builtin, other
00368   // compilers default back to the omp locks.  Until compare and swap is
00369   // available for other compilers, gcc should be preferred.
00370   struct Spin_Lock {
00371     Spin_Mutex & m;
00372     explicit Spin_Lock( Spin_Mutex & _m ) : m( _m ) {
00373       while ( !( compare_and_swap( &m.locked, false, true ) ) ) { }
00374     }
00375     ~Spin_Lock() {
00376       #pragma omp atomic
00377       m.locked &= false;
00378     }
00379   };
00380   #else
00381   // no gcc atomic builtins available, so just typedef the omp scoped lock/mutex
00382   typedef Mutex Spin_Mutex;
00383   typedef Scoped_Lock Spin_Lock;
00384   #endif
00385 
00386 
00387 }
